question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
Let A be the matrix for the linear transformation T. Suppose we know
that $\mathbf{v}_1=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_2=\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_3=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}$ are eigenvectors of A
associated to the eigenvalues $\lambda=1$, $\lambda=2$, and $\lambda=3$
respectively.

Find the matrix A.
sols:
For any matrix A and basis vector $\mathbf{e}_i$ computing

\begin{align*}A\mathbf{e}_i\end{align*}

obtains column i of A. If A is our linear transformation matrix then
computing $A\mathbf{e}_1$, $A\mathbf{e}_2$, and $A\mathbf{e}_3$ will
give us the three columns of A and hence we'll know the matrix. From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(b)}{part
(b)}, we already determined the transformation on the vector
$\mathbf{e}_1$,

\begin{align*}A\mathbf{e}_1=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

and so this is the first column of A. To get the other relations we can
use our work from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)}{part
(a)} where we obtained the basis vectors in terms of the eigenvectors.
For $\mathbf{e}_2$ we have

\begin{align*}\mathbf{e}_2=\mathbf{v}_1-\mathbf{v}_3\end{align*}

and so

\begin{align*}A\mathbf{e}_2=A\mathbf{v}_1-A\mathbf{v}_3=\mathbf{v}_1-3\mathbf{v}_3=
\begin{bmatrix}
-2\\
1\\
-2
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

where we have used the eigenvalue/eigenvector relationships. This is the
second column of A. Finally for $\mathbf{e}_3$ we have from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)}{part
(a)},

\begin{align*}\mathbf{e}_3=-\mathbf{v}_1+\mathbf{v}_2+\mathbf{v}_3\end{align*}

and so

\begin{align*}A\mathbf{e}_2=-A\mathbf{v}_1+A\mathbf{v}_2+A\mathbf{v}_3=-\mathbf{v}_1+2\mathbf{v}_2+3\mathbf{v}_3=
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
1\\
4
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

gives us the third column of A. Therefore we have that the linear
transformation matrix A is

\begin{align*}A=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  -2  &  2\\
-1  &  1  &  1\\
-1  &  -2  &  4
\end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}
hints: How can we use the basis vectors to build the transformation matrix?

Use the work from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)}{part
(a)} and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(b)}{part
(b)} to determine how the basis vectors are transformed using the
eigenvectors.
